snippet: For generations, Spaniards have left their homes in the country to seek jobs in the city, but now many are moving back.
abstract: Villanueva de la Vera Journal; Spain's economic crisis is breathing new life into movement that some sociologists have dubbed 'rurbanismo,' or the reverse migration from city to country; some of these new migrants are returning to the villages where they grew up or where earlier generations of their family lived, sometimes taking over property that had been left empty or used only for vacations.
lead_paragraph: For generations, Spaniards have left their homes in the country to seek jobs in the city, but now many are moving back.

headline.seo: Spain’s Economy Sends City Residents Back to Country
headline.main: The Country Beckons Spaniards as Jobs in Cities Grow Scarce
headline.print_headline: The Country Beckons Spaniards as Jobs in Cities Grow Scarce
